Create a written Conflict Resolution Protocol document that includes: (1) immediate verbal de-escalation techniques, (2) mandatory 24-hour cooling-off period for non-emergency disputes, (3) structured mediation meeting format with neutral facilitator, (4) documentation requirements using incident report forms, and (5) escalation path from verbal warning → written warning → final warning → eviction consideration under three-strike policy

Establish a tiered response system: Level 1 (minor disputes like TV remote arguments) = staff mediation within 2 hours; Level 2 (verbal altercations, property disputes) = house manager mediation within 24 hours with written incident report; Level 3 (threats, physical altercations, safety concerns) = immediate separation of residents, incident report filed within 1 hour, and coordination with crisis intervention or Adult Protective Services if vulnerable adults involved

Design a standardized Incident Report Form that captures: date/time, residents involved, witnesses present, detailed description of conflict, immediate actions taken, resident statements (signed), staff observations, photos of any property damage, and follow-up plan—store all reports in locked file cabinet for minimum 7 years per state record retention laws

Create a Written Warning template that includes: specific rule violation cited from resident handbook (e.g., 'Section 4.2: No verbal threats toward other residents'), date/time of incident, consequences of repeated violation, resident acknowledgment signature, witness signature, and clear statement of strike count (e.g., 'This is your first written warning under our three-strike policy')

Develop a Mediation Meeting Script for staff to follow: (1) Meet in neutral space (dining room, not either resident's bedroom), (2) Each resident gets 5 uninterrupted minutes to explain their perspective, (3) Staff summarizes each position to confirm understanding, (4) Residents propose solutions, (5) Staff facilitates agreement on specific behavioral changes (e.g., 'John will use headphones after 9pm, Mike will keep his belongings in his room only'), (6) Both residents sign agreement, (7) Follow-up check-in scheduled for 3 days later

Research your state's eviction laws specific to residential care facilities—for example, California requires 30-day written notice for eviction without cause but allows 3-day notice for serious violations; consult with local housing attorney ($200-400 consultation) to create state-compliant eviction notice templates and understand required documentation for legal eviction if three-strike policy is exhausted

Establish relationships BEFORE conflicts arise: get contact information for county Adult Protective Services (APS) hotline for residents over 65 or with disabilities, local crisis intervention team or mobile mental health unit for psychiatric emergencies (often dispatched through 911 or dedicated crisis line), and identify 2-3 backup placement options (other group homes, temporary respite care, or assisted living facilities) that could accept a resident within 24-72 hours if immediate removal is necessary for safety

Create a Conflict Prevention Checklist for daily operations: (1) Post house rules visibly in common areas, (2) Conduct weekly house meetings where residents can voice concerns before they escalate, (3) Assign private storage space to each resident to prevent property disputes, (4) Establish TV/common area rotation schedule to prevent entertainment conflicts, (5) Train staff to recognize early warning signs (residents avoiding each other, passive-aggressive comments, increased isolation)

Implement a Boundary Maintenance Policy for staff: prohibit staff from taking sides in resident disputes, ban staff from sharing personal phone numbers or social media with residents, require staff to redirect residents seeking personal advice to appropriate professionals (therapist, case manager), and document any boundary violations by staff in personnel files—maintaining professional distance prevents conflicts of interest and ensures fair mediation

Develop a Post-Conflict Monitoring Plan: after any Level 2 or Level 3 incident, assign staff to conduct daily check-ins with involved residents for 7 days, document any tension or repeated issues in shift notes, adjust room assignments if residents cannot coexist peacefully (move to different floors or opposite ends of house), and schedule follow-up mediation at 7-day and 30-day marks to ensure resolution is holding

Create an Emergency Safety Protocol for conflicts involving immediate danger: (1) Separate residents to different areas of house immediately, (2) Call 911 if physical violence occurs or threats are credible, (3) Document with photos/video if safe to do so, (4) Contact residents' emergency contacts and case managers within 2 hours, (5) File police report if assault occurred (required for insurance claims and legal protection), (6) Consult attorney within 24 hours about emergency eviction if resident poses ongoing safety threat

Establish a Resident Agreement Addendum specifically for conflict resolution: require all residents to sign acknowledgment that they will (1) participate in mediation when requested by staff, (2) accept cooling-off periods (temporary separation to different areas), (3) comply with written warnings and behavioral agreements, (4) understand that three documented violations of house rules may result in eviction per state law—having signed agreement strengthens legal position if eviction becomes necessary

Create a daily maintenance checklist covering 8 critical areas: plumbing (check for leaks under sinks, toilets, water heater), electrical (test GFCI outlets monthly, check for flickering lights), HVAC (replace filters monthly $15-30 each, listen for unusual noises), doors/locks (test all entry points, lubricate hinges quarterly), windows (check seals, test locks), appliances (inspect refrigerator coils, test smoke/CO detectors monthly), exterior (check gutters, downspouts, foundation cracks), and common areas (inspect furniture stability, check flooring for trip hazards)

Establish a maintenance log system using free Google Sheets or Buildium property management software ($50/month) with columns for: date discovered, location, issue description, severity level (emergency/urgent/routine), resident who reported, date resolved, cost, and contractor used - this documentation protects you in liability claims and helps track recurring issues

Set up a resident reporting system using Google Voice (free) or dedicated maintenance request line where residents can text or call 24/7 - respond to emergency issues (no heat in winter, no water, gas smell, electrical sparking) within 2 hours, urgent issues (clogged toilet, broken lock) within 24 hours, and routine issues (squeaky door, paint touch-up) within 7 days per standard landlord-tenant law

Conduct weekly walk-throughs every Monday morning from 9-11am inspecting all common areas, bathrooms, kitchen, and exterior - use your smartphone to photograph any issues with timestamp for documentation, and knock on resident doors to ask 'Any maintenance concerns this week?' to catch problems before they escalate

Build a vetted contractor list with 2-3 contacts for each trade: plumber ($75-150/hour), electrician ($80-120/hour), HVAC technician ($100-200 service call), handyman ($40-60/hour), locksmith ($75-150 emergency), and appliance repair ($80-150 service call) - get quotes from each before hiring and verify they carry liability insurance and workers' comp

Stock a basic maintenance supply kit ($200-300 initial investment) including: plunger, toilet auger, adjustable wrench, screwdriver set, hammer, drill with bits, GFCI tester, flashlight, ladder, caulk gun with silicone, plumber's tape, air filters (buy 12 at once for $180/year savings), light bulbs (LED 60W equivalent), smoke detector batteries (9V), cleaning supplies, and touch-up paint matching your walls

Implement preventive maintenance schedule: HVAC filters first Monday of each month ($15-30), smoke/CO detector testing second Monday ($0, just press test button), GFCI outlet testing third Monday (press test/reset buttons), water heater flush annually ($0 DIY or $100 professional), dryer vent cleaning every 6 months ($100-150 or $0 DIY), and gutter cleaning twice yearly ($100-200 per cleaning) - preventive maintenance costs $500-800/year but prevents $3,000-5,000 emergency repairs

Establish emergency response protocols: post emergency contact numbers (your cell, backup manager, plumber, electrician, HVAC, poison control 1-800-222-1222, non-emergency police) on refrigerator and in each resident room - for after-hours emergencies (10pm-7am), assess if truly urgent or can wait until morning to avoid $150-300 emergency service premiums

Create a maintenance budget of 1-2% of property value annually (e.g., $200,000 home = $2,000-4,000/year or $165-335/month) and track all expenses in QuickBooks Self-Employed ($15/month) or Wave (free) - categorize as repairs (tax deductible immediately) vs improvements (depreciate over 27.5 years) per IRS Publication 527

Inspect resident rooms quarterly (with 24-hour written notice per landlord-tenant law) for unreported damage, cleanliness issues, fire hazards (overloaded outlets, blocked exits), or unauthorized modifications - document with photos and address issues within 7 days to prevent security deposit disputes and maintain property value

Set up seasonal maintenance calendar: Spring (check AC before summer, clean gutters, inspect roof, power wash exterior $150-300), Summer (trim trees/bushes away from house, check foundation for cracks, test sprinkler system), Fall (check furnace before winter, clean gutters again, weatherstrip doors/windows $50-100), Winter (check for ice dams, test pipes in freezing weather, salt walkways $20/bag)

Establish a maintenance reserve fund separate from operating account with $3,000-5,000 minimum (covers typical emergency repairs like water heater replacement $800-1,500, HVAC repair $300-1,000, or plumbing emergency $200-800) - replenish monthly by setting aside $200-400 from resident payments to avoid cash flow crises when major repairs hit

At 7:00 AM daily, walk through all common areas (living room, kitchen, bathrooms, hallways) with a printed checklist covering: smoke detectors functional, fire extinguishers accessible, exit routes clear, no tripping hazards, all lights working, no water leaks, doors/locks functioning properly
Test all smoke detectors by pressing test button - document any non-functional units in incident log (T218) and replace 9V batteries immediately (keep 12-pack on hand, $15 at Walmart)
Check all exit doors and windows to ensure they open freely without obstruction - verify no furniture, boxes, or items block evacuation routes per local fire code requirements

Inspect kitchen for safety hazards: stove/oven turned off, no grease buildup, refrigerator at 40°F or below (use $8 thermometer), no expired food creating health risks, fire extinguisher accessible within 10 feet

Walk exterior perimeter checking: all exterior doors lock properly, no broken windows, handrails secure on stairs/ramps, adequate outdoor lighting functional, no standing water creating slip hazards, trash bins not overflowing

Check HVAC function (T215) by verifying thermostat reads within 3°F of set temperature - if variance exceeds this, document in maintenance log and call HVAC technician same day to prevent resident complaints

Inspect all bathrooms for: working toilets (no running water), functional sinks with hot water, no mold/mildew on surfaces, grab bars secure (test with 50-pound pull), non-slip mats in showers, adequate ventilation

Document completion of walk-through in daily operations log with timestamp, initial findings, and any corrective actions taken - use simple Google Sheet template with columns: Date, Time, Inspector Name, Issues Found, Action Taken, Follow-up Required

If any safety issue cannot be immediately corrected (broken lock, HVAC failure, water leak), notify all residents verbally within 30 minutes and post written notice on common area bulletin board with expected resolution timeline

Review security camera footage (T217) if any resident reported concerns overnight or if walk-through reveals unexplained damage - save relevant clips to dated folder on external hard drive for 90-day retention

Take photos of any damage or safety concerns discovered using smartphone with timestamp enabled - store in Google Drive folder organized by date for insurance/liability documentation and resident billing if applicable

Document the exact incident time from staff reports or resident statements, then review footage starting 15 minutes before the reported incident through 15 minutes after to capture full context and any escalation patterns

Create a dedicated incident folder on your computer or cloud storage (Google Drive free, Dropbox $11.99/month) labeled by date and incident type (e.g., '2024-01-15_Resident_Altercation', '2024-01-20_Property_Damage_Kitchen')

Use your camera system's clip/download feature to save the relevant 5-15 minute footage segment as a video file with clear timestamp metadata - most systems allow MP4 downloads that preserve date/time stamps for legal documentation

Take screenshots of key moments showing: involved parties entering/exiting the area, the actual incident occurrence, any witnesses present, and the resolution/aftermath - save as JPG files with descriptive names like 'Kitchen_Incident_Resident_A_Entry_10-23am.jpg'

Cross-reference the footage with your incident log (T218) to verify staff reports are accurate, noting any discrepancies such as timeline differences, unreported individuals present, or conflicting accounts of what occurred

If footage shows policy violations (unauthorized guests, substance use, aggressive behavior), document specific timestamps and actions visible on camera to support any resident counseling, lease violation notices, or potential eviction proceedings per your house rules

Share relevant footage clips with your liability insurance provider within 48 hours if the incident involves injury, property damage over $500, or potential legal claims - most insurers require prompt incident reporting with supporting documentation

For incidents involving potential criminal activity (assault, theft, vandalism), save footage to a USB drive and provide copies to local police within 24 hours along with your incident report and any witness statements from staff or residents

Review footage from 7 days prior to any serious incident to identify warning signs or pattern behaviors (repeated arguments between specific residents, unauthorized visitors, substance use indicators) that could have been addressed earlier through intervention

If cameras captured a resident medical emergency, review footage to document response times: when staff first noticed the issue, when 911 was called, when emergency services arrived - critical for liability protection and proving proper duty of care

Store all incident-related footage for minimum 90 days (check your state's requirements - some require 6-12 months retention) and maintain a footage log spreadsheet tracking: date, incident type, camera location, footage duration, and where files are stored

For every new referral received (even if not placed), respond within 4 hours with status update - either 'We can accommodate, here's next steps' or 'Currently full, but I've added them to waitlist and will call you when space opens' to build reputation for responsiveness
Set up a Google Voice number ($0/month) or dedicated business line specifically for referral source calls so you can track and prioritize these contacts separately from resident/family calls

Create maintenance reserve tracking spreadsheet with columns: Date, Deposit Amount, Withdrawal Amount, Reason for Withdrawal, Running Balance, and categorize withdrawals (Plumbing, HVAC, Appliances, Structural, Emergency) to identify spending patterns

Review reserve usage quarterly to identify preventive maintenance opportunities: if spending $100+/month on plumbing calls, invest $500 from reserves for whole-house pipe inspection to prevent future emergencies and reduce long-term reserve drain

Create a separate line item in your accounting software labeled 'Vacancy Buffer (15%)' to track this deduction from gross revenue projections

Apply the vacancy-adjusted revenue ($4,845 in example) when calculating your profit margin against total monthly expenses (lease + utilities $400-600 + internet $100 + maintenance $150 + insurance $200 + supplies $100 + marketing $50 + misc $100)
Set aside the actual vacancy buffer amount ($855 in example) in a separate savings account as cash reserve for months when beds are unfilled

Document your vacancy assumptions in financial projections shown to landlords or investors, stating '15% vacancy buffer applied per industry standard for residential care facilities'
Track actual vacancy rate monthly by calculating (empty bed-days ÷ total bed-days available) × 100 to validate if 15% buffer is appropriate for your market

Use vacancy buffer funds only for covering fixed expenses (lease, insurance, utilities) during actual vacancy periods - never for discretionary spending or expansion costs

Set room rental rates at $500-$700/month per room based on local market research, targeting total rental income of $1,500-$2,100/month from 3 rooms to cover or exceed your mortgage payment

Use the $400-$800/month savings from eliminated housing costs plus your day job income to build capital for your first official group home property, targeting $10,000-$15,000 saved within 12-18 months for rental arbitrage security deposits

Document all rental income, expenses, and property management activities to build your track record for future lender applications, showing 12+ months of successful tenant management and positive cash flow

Maintain separate spaces and establish house rules similar to group home operations: quiet hours, shared common areas, individual room privacy, and monthly house meetings to develop your management skills

After 12 months of successful house hacking, use your equity (property appreciation plus mortgage paydown of approximately $3,000-$5,000) and saved capital to either refinance for investment property purchase or launch your first 6-bed rental arbitrage group home

Transition house hack property to full investment property once you move into your group home facility, converting your owner-occupied loan to rental property and increasing room count to 4-5 beds for $2,500-$3,500/month total revenue
